Input.posts:
The why scale matters example brought to mind one of the biggest issues we have in my field which is the need for disaggregated data. One example was when I worked in California researching the Asian American community. It's so diverse that lumping everyone of Asian heritage into one dataset makes it diffcult to pull out the communities that have unique health issues or are in greater need of social services. Writing grants and having to demontrate need in certain communities and map this was made difficult because if we only had county or state level data on Asian Americans, it looked like a pretty rosy picture. The higher income Asian American groups washed out the fact that Bengalis and Hmong communities had income levels at or below the poverty level and were in need of certain services.
Upvotes:
4
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
You're absolutely right, Tina. And at the same time, we often want disaggregated data because it's more likely to protect individual privacy. So it's a tricky situation. You'll often see county-level maps as the finest-grained health outcome data, for example, because anything below that can frequently result in privacy issues for patients and their families. I've worked on projects where even the county-level units weren't big enough due to small numbers in population segments (e.g. black males aged 65+ with colon cancer in a rural pennsylvania county). So I'm not sure how to get around these issues, as both are important. On one hand, it's important to protect people's privacy. On the other hand, by being sensitive to privacy, we also risk overlooking the outliers that actually deserve a great deal of attention. What do you think are some ways to map around both of these imperatives? Can we do both of these things at once?
